qas.question: Does intimacy between same-sex siblings increase or decrease during adolescence?
When siblings act as peers, what positive effects are possible?

answers.text: increase one another's sociability and feelings of self-worth

qas.question: At what stage to mixed-sex siblings generally experience an increase in intimacy?

context: During childhood, siblings are a source of conflict and frustration as well as a support system. Adolescence may affect this relationship differently, depending on sibling gender. In same-sex sibling pairs, intimacy <a0_0>increases<a0_0/> during early adolescence, then remains stable. Mixed-sex siblings pairs act differently; siblings drift apart during early adolescent years, but experience an increase in intimacy starting at <a2_0>middle adolescence<a2_0/>. Sibling interactions are children's first relational experiences, the ones that shape their social and self-understanding for life. Sustaining positive sibling relations can assist adolescents in a number of ways. Siblings are able to act as peers, and may <a1_0>increase one another's sociability and feelings of self-worth<a1_0/>. Older siblings can give guidance to younger siblings, although the impact of this can be either positive or negative depending on the activity of the older sibling.
